semantic_title: Codes for Symptoms, Signs, and Ill-Defined Conditions - Restrictions for Principal Diagnosis Use
section_path: Section II > Selection of Principal Diagnosis > A. Codes for symptoms, signs, and ill-defined conditions

content.full_text: Codes for symptoms, signs, and ill-defined conditions from Chapter 18 are not to be used as principal diagnosis when a related definitive diagnosis has been established. (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101-L102)
content.summary: Restriction on using Chapter 18 symptom codes as principal diagnosis when definitive diagnoses are available (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101-L102)
key_concepts: Chapter 18 codes restricted as principal diagnosis when definitive diagnosis exists (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101-L102)
Definitive diagnosis takes precedence over symptom codes (Evidence: pg no: 108, L102)
Applies specifically to related definitive diagnoses (Evidence: pg no: 108, L102)

detailed_rules.rule_text: Chapter 18 codes not used as principal diagnosis when related definitive diagnosis established (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101-L102)
detailed_rules.explanation: When a definitive diagnosis that explains the symptoms has been established, the definitive diagnosis must be used as principal diagnosis instead of the symptom code (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101-L102)

workflow_steps: Step 1: Identify if Chapter 18 code is being considered for principal diagnosis
Step 2: Review documentation for related definitive diagnosis
Step 3: If definitive diagnosis established, use it as principal diagnosis
Step 4: Use symptom code as secondary diagnosis if still relevant

code_ranges.description: Symptoms, signs and abnormal clinical and laboratory findings, not elsewhere classified (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101)
code_ranges.requirement: Not to be used as principal diagnosis when related definitive diagnosis established
usage_rules: Use definitive diagnosis as principal when available (Evidence: pg no: 108, L102)

code_patterns.description: Chapter 18 symptom and sign codes (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101)
code_patterns.example: R06.02 Shortness of breath, R50.9 Fever unspecified
code_patterns.explanation: These codes should not be principal diagnosis when related definitive diagnosis exists

coding_scenarios.scenario: Patient admitted with shortness of breath, diagnosed with pneumonia after chest X-ray
coding_scenarios.documentation_example: Patient admitted with chief complaint of shortness of breath. Chest X-ray revealed pneumonia. Treated with antibiotics.
step_by_step: Step 1: Identify presenting symptom (shortness of breath - R06.02)
Step 2: Review for definitive diagnosis (pneumonia established)
Step 3: Determine relationship (shortness of breath related to pneumonia)
Step 4: Use pneumonia as principal diagnosis

correct_coding.rationale: Definitive diagnosis of pneumonia established, related to presenting symptom (Evidence: pg no: 108, L101-L102)

incorrect_coding.rationale: Should not use symptom code as principal when related definitive diagnosis established
incorrect_coding.common_mistake: Using presenting symptom as principal diagnosis when definitive diagnosis available

warnings: Must establish relationship between symptom and definitive diagnosis (Evidence: pg no: 108, L102)
Applies only when definitive diagnosis has been established (Evidence: pg no: 108, L102)
best_practices: Always review for definitive diagnoses before using symptom codes as principal
Ensure symptom and definitive diagnosis are related
Use symptom codes as secondary when still clinically relevant
common_mistakes: Using symptom codes as principal when definitive diagnosis available
Not recognizing relationship between symptoms and established diagnoses
Misunderstanding when definitive diagnosis has been established
tips: Look for diagnostic test results that establish definitive diagnoses
Consider whether symptoms are explained by established diagnoses
Review complete clinical picture for diagnostic clarity
implementation_notes: Requires clinical judgment to determine relationships
Important for accurate principal diagnosis selection
